text: I seem to have stumbled upon a Real Ale tap takeover at Hughies as only 6 of the 20 taps are other brands. This one is hazy auburn with a finger of tan foam. Big aroma of dried cherries and other dark fruits, caramel and toffee. Taste is more of the same plus a strong boozy kick.
Tap at Petrol - murky, brown, wimpy head. Nice aroma, dark fruits, tea leaves, caramel. Very good on the tongue.... Caramel, earthiness, wood, slight booziness, very well done. One of their best.
Draft at whip-in. Pours a cloudy brownish red color. Quarter inch white head. Paint thinner and plums. Currant and plums flavor. Medium mouthfeel. Light sourness.

Tap at Real Ale brewery. Aroma: Malty, Scotch aroma; Appearance: dark amber with white head; Taste: definitely boozy as if from Scotch barrel; malty, sweet; Palate: odd aftertaste that wasnt completely pleasant; heavy body: Overall: disappointing; would probably not get again.
(En fût à Hopfields): Ça goûte exactement le Porto. Douceur boisée, tabac, épices, purée de mûres et une agréable légèreté.

On tap at the Big Texas Beer Fest. Poured an unfiltered murky brown with a beige head. Taste of caramel malts, sweet, dark fruits, with a warming boozy finish. Average carbonation, medium body. Damn good brew!

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2015 Take a whiff only if youre willing to drown in strong raisins, caramel, Guinness fudge, and oaky vanilla notes. Oh, Son of Mary. Unlike anything else. It continues with plums, preserved figs, and other dried fruits that give way to some of the breadier malty notes and a hint of peat and booze. The mouthfeel is firm but silky, with low carbonation and a dense body. The sugary, fruity sweetness overpowers the bitterness on the palate and conceals the alcohol well. Would make a hearty followup to a nice chunk of ribeye. A sumptuous dessert and a dangerous beast unto itself. Silly good.
Pours a reddish brown color with off-white head. Oak, dark fruits, scotch, sweetness, and some nuts on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes warming.
On tap at World of Beer. Hazy brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is of heavy peat, wood, smoke, plum, raisin, leather. Taste is of peat, smoke, leather, raisin, whiskey and oak.
The look is a off white head, murky, and reddish brown in color. The smell. Is melted caramels, sweet, syrup, wood, scotch, whiskey, and nice. The taste is much the same, boozy, and good.

Hand bottle thanks to errl. Poured into a brandy snifter. Pours a murky brown with a thin, beige head of foam. The aroma is very wine forward and initially made me think this was going to be sour. The taste lent nothing of the sort. Being into that sort of thing, I was just slightly let down about that. The taste was more red wine and earthy sweetness. Some fruity complexities snuck in there as well. Nice barrel treatment. Kind of wish I had opened it a little sooner.

Hand bottle extra from errl. Youre the man. Deep cloudy brown. Thought this was bourbon barrel aged from the initial nose....lots of vanilla barrel characteristics and super caramel and toffee malts, light smoke maybe some dried orange peel. Taste is sweet malty core but cleansing red wine tannins and tardiness shows through with a lingering peaty smokiness. Really unique and all works well together. Tad hot.

Murky red brown pour with no head. Aroma is tart berries, caramel, and strong barrel. Tart has an initial tart fruitiness to that goes into caramel and brown sugar sweetness. Wood and some tannic qualities are also in there. Slick texture. This is an interesting beer.

Nice twist on the real heavy. Pleasant sweet malt aroma associated with Scotch Ale with an additional fruity twist. Very dark brown with a minimal head. Smooth and oily. Sharp caramel flavors with an alcohol bite. The oak became apparent about half-way through with a mix of dryness I guess came from the wine barrel. Good strong stuff.

Draft at Mellow Mushroom Spring TX. Brown and murky with no head. Its ugly. But one sniff of the big barrel aging brings this to life. Taste is full of barrel, some sweetness thats not offputting (not a fan of too sweet beers) and goes down way too easy. Alcohol is present but fits in. Very nice!
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Muddy brownish color with a thin head. Aroma full of fruit and wood. Taste is sweet malt and fruit with plenty of wood and some booze. Nice.

Pours a murky, swampy amber with a thin white head. Smells like cranberry and whiskey. Tastes of various dark fruits, candy and light malt. Sweet with a light, creamy mouthfeel. Packed with flavor. Pretty good and very unique.

On tap.
Amber orange brew with a ring of off-white head.  Nose is very fruity and sweet with caramel, vanilla, and oak.  Flavor is woody with lots of dark fruit.
Tap at brewery, RateBeer Winter Gathering 12 Pours a deep amber with a nose of cedar planks and raisin dough.  Flavor is cinnamon raisin bread.  Chunky mouthfeel.  Another winner.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Growler- Pour is murky amber with ruby tint..Nose is cranberry,sugar cane,berries,wine,sweet,fruity,light tart..Taste is caramel,wet wood,wine,fruit juice,sweet,alcohol..palate is warm and sweet
Clear light brown color with tan head. Big bourbon, wood char, smoke, caramel aromas. medium body. Rich bourbon, wood char, toffee, spicy caramel flavors--good
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Deep amber pour. Nice light malt aroma with vanilla, and abv. Sweet caramel malt with abv warmth. Medium bodied and fizzy. Pretty nice beer
On tap at the brewery, RBWG 2012. Clear amber with a nice off white head, smells of caramel, scotch, Smokey and woody, taste is toasted malts, caramel, peat and vanilla. A nice scotch ale

2/24/12. On tap at the brewery during RBWG 2012. Almost clear light amber pour with a small khaki head. Woody barrel character, lots of wood, with vanilla, wood, and sweet caramels. Sweet caramel flavor with plenty of wood and vanilla as well. Not too shabby.

Tap@ the Flying Saucer! .. Pours a tan brown .. . quite hot, great foam .. . brandy, oak and merlot wine .. . balanced in a twisted way .. . good but huge and abominable .. . No, wasps do not make honey. 
All right, well, Im gonna check it out anyway; there could be something delicious in here that wasps do make, and I want that.

On tap at the RealTail party.  Poured a clear, glowing scotch-colored (go figure) body and some off-white head.  Red wine, caramel, peat and some smoke on the nose.  Flavors were toasty, peaty, alcoholy, some sour and some whiskey.  Coarse, active carbonation with a medium mouthfeel.  A good choice for barrel aging.

Tap at Freetail. A caramel brown color beer with no head. The aroma is sweet, vanilla, and a really nice bourbon scent that was not overpowering but just enough to be there. I really could not stop smelling this. The taste was sweet, boubon, caramel, port or sherry like and was my favorite of the Real Ale barrel aged beers that day.
On tap at Real Tail event at Freetail. Copper color with light white head. Aroma is sweet bourbon, port wine and old grape juice. Flavor is sweet with hints of bourbon and wine. Different.

On tap at RealTail at Freetail Brewing Co in San Antonio on July 17, 2010.  Ive waited a ling time for this.  Highlander has an orange-mahogany color, no carbonation, and a white head.  Nose of oak, malt, and moss.  A divine smell!  Thin mouth feel, but a wacky delicious flavor with dark sugars, a little sour bite at the back of the jaw, and hints of raisins or currants with rum.  Super-sized oak portions with a long-lasting alcoholic malt finish.  Thinner than the standard Real Heavy from what I remember.  Worth waiting for.

Draught. Nose is very sweet with lots of fruit and oak character. Cherries, strawberry, fig. Pours ruby with no head. Sweet and heavy, but still drinkable. Cherries, peaches, various citrus fruits, figs, oak, sherry, and caramel malt. All in good balance. Chewy, thick, alcoholic, but not overbearing.

On tap at the Garland Flying Saucer.

The beer pours a brownish-red color with a white head. The aroma is oak, caramel malt and dark fruit. The flavor is a complicated mix of alcohol, caramel malt, syrup, oak, dark fruit, brown sugar and some smoke. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Pours apricot colored with a thin white head. Fruity wod aroma, peat, smoke, and frost. Light syrup consistency. Hides alcohol well. Dry finish. Delicious really.
light red more on orange shade. no head to speak of. smell of grapes and achohol taste is real heavy malt with lots grape from barrels finish is nice overall
On tap at the Fort Worth Gingerman.  Dark orange pour with an off-white head.  Aroma is faint. Sweet spice, alcohol, honey, dark fruit, and brown sugar.  Taste is tart, honey, plum, and cinnamon.

Tap at Gman FW. Slightly hazy reddish orange appearance with a white fading head. Aroma is off the bat alcohol. Sweet fruit and white wine nose. Smelling some wood, but not oak specifically. I almost hate to say it but I am pulling a cider quality here. Apple juice scents. Thick mouthfeel. Immediate alcohol flavor, wood, heavy fruit. Some dry malts near the end accompanied with a prompt alcohol burn. Stronger than actual taste. Wow.
deep ruby/brown with a thin cream head.  mode is wood, sticky caramel, dried fruits and more caramel.  nice palate, flavors of caramel, dried fruits, wood and no hint of alcohol.

(draught at Flying Saucer Addison) clear orange brown with ring of light tan bubbles. Nose of honey, caramel, wood, light alcohol. Taste of alcohol, caramel, maple, raisins and other dried fruits. Body is light to medium, dried fruit finish and some maple in the finish.

On tap at the Addison Saucer...$14! And its not a pint!! Smal tan head over a hazy amber brown body. Brown sugar, figs, toffee, vinous. Raisins, treacle, chai tea, plum. Some very light oak tannins in the finish. Oak, brown sugar, raisins, vinous, tons of dark fruit, cherry, slightest hint of smoke. Brandy. Creamy carbonation. Really pretty tasty, and a lot better than the regular, but at $14 I think Ill pass on a second glass...
Poured a dark amber with little to no head. A bit hot on the tip of the tongue. A bit orf tartness in the back. Heavy malts shine through.

On tap at flying saucer. Pours a cloudy dark amber with a medium off white head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is a a sweet raisin malt and fruity red wine. Medium mouthfeel with a rich malt with the wine coming through and lingering in the finish. Hides the alcohol well making it easy to drink.  A very impressive scotch ale from Real Ale.

( 750ml bottle, courtesy of Real Ale )  Pours a hazy orangish brown body with a small beige head.  Aroma of wood, vinous, caramel, nuts, toffee, and peat.  Flavor of wood, roasted malt, peat, vinous, and raisins.
